column4: Hey guys, I need some help.  I unplugged a USB drive from a Mac, and now the disk is unreadable.  I need to figure out how to recover the data, are there any programs in Ubuntu that can do this?
For reference, it's a FAT-32 formatted drive.  I tried a few Windows recovery programs but none of them worked
look at fsck.vfat
I'm a bit hesitant to use fsck because I'm worried it'll write to my drive if I set the wrong options.  Maybe my worries are unfounded and I should use it anyway
make a binary image of it with dd
dd if=/dev/usb of=usbimage
that's a good idea.  I'll do that. ActionParsnip, thanks for the suggestion, I'll try that too
fsck is returning an error.  It says : "only 1 or 2 FATs are supported, not 235."
maybe it only does fat and fat16
it supports FAT32.  I just don't know if it recognizes my disk as such
the partition doesn't show up.  It simply says /dev/sdb
try fsck.vfat /dev/sdb1
No such file or directory
the best luck I've had so far was with GetDataBack (a Windows program).  It was able to recover most of the files except for the most recent ones, and the directory names got all scrambled up
I use it all the time, its pretty good
do you know if it's possible to get directory names back?
I usually just take what it gives
foremost wont find much more than getdataback, but its a try
do you know if foremost tries to get the directories back too?
it doesnt
its a forensics application, its there to look at descriptors of files rather than recover them.
gl im off to bed
thanks!
